title: 15 Safe, Non-Toxic Home Cleaning Techniques
ingredients: All-purpose Cleaner
Make a mixture of ½ cup vinegar with ¼ cup baking soda (this can be substituted with 2 teaspoons borax) and stir into ½ gallon of water. This can be stored and kept.
Air Fresheners
Commercial air fresheners basically coat nasal passages and mask smells to diminish odor.
Vinegar or baking soda with lemon juice mixed in small dishes absorbs odors.
Household plants help reduce odors.
Fresh coffee grounds on the counter absorb odors.
For odors in the garbage disposal, grind up a slice of lemon and run it through the garbage disposal.
Cinnamon or other spices can be simmered in water on the stove.
Fragrant dried herbs or flowers can be placed in a bowl in any room.
Bathroom Mold
One part hydrogen peroxide (3%) should be mixed with two parts water inside of a spray bottle. This can be sprayed on areas with mold. Wait about an hour then rinse off.
Carpet Stains
Equal parts white vinegar and water should be mixed in a spray bottle. Spray this directly onto the stain and let it sit for a few minutes, then clean with a sponge or brush.
Heavy duty carpet cleaner: ¼ cup salt, ¼ cup borax, ¼ cup vinegar. Rub this paste into the carpet and let sit for a few hours, and then vacuum.
Fresh grease spots: put some corn starch onto spot, wait 15 to 30 minutes before vacuuming.
Dish Washing Soap
Add 2 to 3 tablespoons of vinegar to water that is warm and soapy.
Disinfectant
Mix 2 teaspoons of borax, 4 tablespoons of vinegar, and 3 cups of hot water. Add ¼ teaspoon of liquid castile soap for a stronger solution.
Dishwasher Soap
Mix equal parts borax and washing soda, increase washing soda for hard water.
Laundry Detergent

For this recipe, you’ll need 1 cup of Ivory soap (or Fels Naptha), ½ cup washing soda, and ½ cup borax should be mixed. Use 1 tablespoon for loads that are light, or 2 tablespoons for loads that are heavy.
Marks on Walls
Apply baking soda to a damp sponge. Gently rub, then wipe and rinse.
Mold & Mildew
Lemon juice or white vinegar should be used at full strength applied with a sponge or scrubby.
Rust Remover
Sprinkle salt on the rust, squeeze a lime over it until it is soaked. Let sit for 2 to 3 hours, and then use the lemon rind to scrub the residue.
Toilet Bowl Cleaner
¼ cup baking soda mixed with 1 cup of vinegar should be poured into the basin and sit for a couple of minutes.
Window Cleaner
2 teaspoons of white vinegar should be mixed with 1 liter of warm water. Crumpled black and white newspaper can be used to rub the mixture on and wipe away debris.
Scouring Powder
Baking soda applied with a damp sponge can be used on surfaces that can’t be scratched like a stove top or refrigerator.
Shoe Polish
Olive oil with a few drops of lemon juice can be applied to shoes with a cotton rag. Leave for a few minutes, then wipe off and buff with a dry, clean rag.
